# An example pipeline based around delta files using Python and SQL
- This pipeline would be triggered as new data is added to the blob storage, or timed to run on a regular basis, we could even stream data live through it. The entire notebook would be run at once meaning we wouldn't be orcestrating multiple components together.
- Read CSV files that have been added to blob storage by an external process and write these as delta files to our raw zone
- Read the delta files in our raw zone, conduct some data cleansing and write to our cleansed zone as well as create tables associated with these files in our cleansed database
- Read the delta files in our cleaned zone, model them by applying business logic and write these into our model zone as well as creating associated tables in our model database

## Benefits of using delta files
- Simple: a single file structure in which new data is added, rather than having to combine together multiple files to create the current version of a file
- Compressed and fast: they are instantiated at the base level as parquet files
- Can travel back in time to previous versions of the delta file, for instance if problematic data was added and we want to go back to an older version, or we want to see how the data has changed through time
- ACID transactions which means if we write to the file and there is a failure during the write operation we will not partial data added, transactions are all or nothing

# Helpers
Define our functions and constants.
We would aim to build up a code base of reusable functions which would be held din helper

# This notebook contains setups and functions

# Imports
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

# constants

# File paths
INGEST_DL = 'abfss://ingestfiles@synapseteststoragebr.dfs.core.windows.net/'
RAW_DL = 'abfss://rawzone@synapseteststoragebr.dfs.core.windows.net/delta/'
CLEAN_DL = 'abfss://cleanedzone@synapseteststoragebr.dfs.core.windows.net/delta/'
MODELLED_DL = 'abfss://modelzone@synapseteststoragebr.dfs.core.windows.net/delta/'

# landed_to_raw() will read from a csv file from landed storage and write to the raw zone
def raw_to_cleaned(landedRelativePath, rawRelativePath):
    df = spark.read.load(INGEST_DL + landedRelativePath, format='csv', header=True)
    df.write.format("delta").mode('append').save(RAW_DL + rawRelativePath) # note the mode append

# Example of function we would put in place for cleaning data, this could be made more complete
def clean_dataframe(df_dirty):
    return df_dirty.dropDuplicates() # get rid of any duplicates

# raw_to_clean() will read a delta file from raw and write to a delta file 
# in overwrite mode to cleaned, applying cleaning function
def raw_to_clean(relativePathRaw, tableName, lakeDatabase):
    df_raw = spark.read.format("delta").load(RAW_DL + relativePathRaw)
    df_cleaned = clean_dataframe(df_raw)
    df_cleaned.write.option("path", CLEAN_DL + tableName).format('delta').mode('overwrite').saveAsTable(lakeDatabase + '.' + tableName) # note the mode overwrite, note that we are saving as a table to add it to the lake database

# Stage 1: Read CSV files from blob storage -> raw zone
- The raw layer will hold all data that has come from the source systems, read and store everything is the important thing here
- Files stored as delta

# read all csv files and write as delta files to the raw layer

landed_to_raw('customers.csv', 'customers') 
landed_to_raw('employees.csv', 'employees') 
landed_to_raw('productcategories.csv', 'productcategories') 
landed_to_raw('orders.csv', 'orders')
landed_to_raw('products.csv', 'products') 
landed_to_raw('productsubcategories.csv', 'productsubcategories') 
landed_to_raw('vendorproduct.csv', 'vendorproduct') 
landed_to_raw('vendors.csv', 'vendors')
## Oh no we have duplicates in our data!

# Stage 2: raw zone -> cleaned zone 
- Clean it and save it as delta to the cleansed layer, create catalogue tables in our cleansed lake database
- Here we provide data that represents the source system tables, cleaned as we require, with data quality checks
- We also add a catalogue table in our lake database if it doesn't exist, this makes it easy for analysts and others to make use of these tables
- If the catalogue table already exists then simply by updating delta file itself the data that appears in the table will also be updated, the table is really just a pointer to the file, but it exists in an organised database like structure

# create silver delta files and catelogue tables

raw_to_clean('productcategories', 'productcategories', 'clean')
raw_to_clean('employees', 'employees', 'clean')
raw_to_clean('customers', 'customers', 'clean')
raw_to_clean('products', 'products', 'clean')
raw_to_clean('productsubcategories', 'productsubcategories', 'clean')
raw_to_clean('vendorproduct', 'vendorproduct', 'clean')
raw_to_clean('vendors', 'vendors', 'clean')

# For the table orders we need to change text strings to dates to get rid of US formatting
df_orders = spark.read.format("delta").load(RAW_DL + 'orders')
df_orders_out = df_orders.select(
    df_orders.SalesOrderID,
    df_orders.SalesOrderDetailID,
    to_date(df_orders.OrderDate, "M/d/yyyy").alias('OrderDate'),
    to_date(df_orders.DueDate, "M/d/yyyy").alias('DueDate'),  
    to_date(df_orders.ShipDate, "M/d/yyyy").alias('ShipDate'),
    df_orders.EmployeeID,
    df_orders.CustomerID,
    df_orders.SubTotal,
    df_orders.TaxAmt,
    df_orders.Freight,
    df_orders.TotalDue,
    df_orders.ProductID,
    df_orders.OrderQty,    
    df_orders.UnitPrice,            
    df_orders.UnitPriceDiscount,
    df_orders.LineTotal)

df_orders_out.write.option("path", CLEAN_DL + 'orders').format('delta').mode('overwrite').saveAsTable('clean.orders')

- Here we transform the data to make it useful for customers and reporting
